ref.mixed-citation:
Dilthey's typology, see "Die Typen der Weltan- schauung und ihre Ausbildung in den metaphysischen Systemen" (1911; Gesammelte Schriften8: 75-118)
Dilthey
Die Typen der Weltanschauung und ihre Ausbildung in den metaphysischen Systemen 75 8 Gesammelte Schriften 1911
1905-10; Gesammelte Schriften7: 79-18879 7 Gesammelte Schriften 1905

Karl Mannheim remarks, alluding to the Kantian tradition, "Epistemology was the first significant philosophical product of the breakdown of the unitary world-view with which the modern era was ushered in.... Epistemology sought to eliminate this uncertainty by taking its point of departure not from a dogmatically taught theory of existence . . . but from an analysis of the knowing subject" (13). 13
Ernst Cassirer's grand synthesis, The Philosophy of Symbolic Forms.
E. D. Hirsch follows Dilthey's method of typological analysis in Wordsworth and Schelling
De Man's understanding of allegory is indebted to Ben- jamin's Origin of German Tragic Drama (1927)
Erich Auerbach's "Figura" (1939)
Gesammelte Aufsätze (55-92). 55
Jean Starobinski, who recognized their importance. See his Words upon Words.
Todorov's "grammar of the Decameron" (Grammaire du Décaméron)
Claudio Guillén in Literature as System
de Man's first chapter, "Semiology and Rhetoric," in Allegories of Reading
Kenneth Burke's Grammar of Motives and Rhetoric of Motives.
Allegories 10 10

Wellek, an émigré scholar who settled in America in the late 1930s, became the founder of a type of comparative literature that kept literary studies from the professional deformation of na- tional ideologies. His most influential work remains Theory of Literature (1949)
Concepts of Criticism (1963)
Foucault's most concise statement is L'Ordre du discours
Heller 67-88. 67

Heller quotes Nietzsche's late, mad letter to Burckhardt: "Dear Herr Professor, when it comes to it I too would very much prefer a professorial chair in Basle to being God; but I did not dare to go as far in my private egoism as to refrain for its sake from the creation of the world . . ." (83). 83
Spitzer's Meisterwerke
"Early English" in John Gross (167-89). 167
E. M. Butler, Paper Boats, ch. 4.
Fritz Ringer's Decline of the German Mandarins.
Bradbrook, and Raymond Williams, Politics and Letters.

Bourne's essay "The Undergraduate" (1915), rpt. in World69, 71.
Bourne
The Undergraduate 69 World 1915
Stephen Spender's The Year of the Young Rebels (141-61) 141
Beard's statement in the New Republic
Max Lerner on Beard in Books That Changed Our Minds.
Stanley Cavell's Senses of Walden (1972)

Raymond Williams has observed, there was a failure to pro- duce a significant Marxist literary criticism. The problem in the thirties was "how to write a different kind of novel or poem. Since literature was class-restrictive, it was the job of a Socialist to break through this restriction, by producing another kind of literature. Questions of literary criticism or literary history thus largely went by the board. . .. In its positive emphasis, the position was not entirely wrong.... But the negative refusal to engage with major theoretical and practical questions in the discipline of English studies itself was a crucial failure" (Politics 45). 45
Hebdige's Subculture
Brownell's Stan- dards
Krieger's Arts on the Level.
F. O. Matthiessen's American Renaissance
D. H. Lawrence's Studies in Classic American Liter- ature
Charles Feidelson's Symbolism and American Literature
John Irwin's American Hieroglyphics.
Marcuse's Eros and Civilization (1955)
Freud's Civilization and Its Discontents (1930).
Fichte's credit that his Bestimmung des Gelehrten
Bachelard's La Flamme d'une chandelle
Jung, Archetypes
Frye's Anatomy of Criticism
Max Lüthi's interesting genre descriptions of Volksmärchen and Volkssage
Bloom's Anxiety of Influence
Johan Huizinga, Homo Ludens, 1938

A. S. Cook of Yale. "The function of the philologist . . . is the endeavor to relive the life of the past; to enter by the imagination into the spiritual experiences of all the historic protagonists of civilization in a given period and area of culture; to think the thoughts, to feel the emotions, to partake the aspirations, recorded in literature; to become one with humanity in the struggles of a given na- tion or race to perceive and attain the ideal of existence (19-20). 19

Propp concludes by quoting from Veselóvskij on contemporary nar- rative literature and its complicated thematic (also psychological) structure and photographic realism. When "this literature will appear to future generations as distant as antiq- uity . . . when the synthesis of time, that great simplifier, in passing over the complexity of phenomena, reduces them to the magnitude of points receding into the distance, then their lines will merge with those which we are now uncovering when we look back at the poetic traditions of the distant past-and the phenomena of schematism and repetition will then be established across the total expanse" (116). 116
Derrida's essay on Levinas in Writing and Difference (79-153) 79
de Man on Lukács in Blindness and Insight (51-59) 51
E. M. Butler's Tyranny of Greece over Germany
Die Fragmente der Vorsokratiker (1903).
Norman O. Brown anticipates Barthes. In a prose as learned, aphoristic, and plaited as Nietz- sche's, Brown carries on the earlier classicist's revolt against Gelehrtenkultur.
